newsitem.title: USA: Oklahoma farmers hold out hope for a wheat crop.
newsitem.headline: Oklahoma farmers hold out hope for a wheat crop.

text.p: Oklahoma farmers continued to assess wheat damage from last month's freeze but few had opted to give up on grain production, the state's agricultural statistics service said in its weekly crop weather report.
"The extent of the freeze damage from three weeks ago is questionable," the report said.

"As a general rule, farmers have still kept grain production in their sights. Cool, wet weather has helped wheat plants in the Panhandle to develop secondary tillers. Rain is needed for the crop in the northeast district. Many fields are not showing a uniform stand."
Wheat was rated 14 percent very poor, 18 percent poor, 35 percent fair, 32 percent good and one percent excellent.
Corn was 33 percent planted, well behind the five-year average of 79 percent.
Soybeans were 18 percent planted, slightly ahead of the five-year average of 17 percent.
Livestock conditions were rated three percent poor, 20 percent fair, 72 percent good and five percent excellent.
Topsoil moisture was rated nil very short, three percent short, 85 percent adequate and 12 surplus.
